choices.D: BFD is not compatible between Cisco IOS XR and Cisco IOS Software.
choices.C: Cisco IOS XR router must use dynamic routing or a static route back to the Cisco IOS router to establish the peer relationship.
choices.A: Cisco IOS XR router must use LDP to route back to the Cisco IOS router to establish the peer relationship.
choices.B: Cisco IOS XR Software does not support BFD multihop for IPv4.

questions.question_text: Which statement about BFD on Cisco IOS XR Software is true?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
It's strange but true!

C
A router running BFD in Cisco IOS software can designate a router running BFD in Cisco IOS XR software as its peer using the bfd neighbor command; the Cisco IOS XR router must use dynamic routing or a static route back to the Cisco IOS router to establish the peer relationship.

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/routers/crs/software/crs_r6-1/routing/configuration/guide/b-routing-cg-crs-61x/b-routing-cg-crs-61x_chapter_0100.html

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. A network engineer implemented this segment routing configuration. Which statement about the output is true?

choices.B: The device must be reloaded for these ranges to be allocated and used.
choices.C: The default segment routing global block range is being used on this device.
choices.A: This range conflicts with the segment routing local block range.
choices.D: A nondefault segment routing global block range is being used on this device.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
We have to just look at the output and based on soles the output, it is answer D. 

As for B, we would only need to reload the router if any of the non-default labels are in use, we are not 100% sure about this.

comments.content: You have one of the newest comments I've seen so far, how did you do on this test?
I didnâ€™t end up taking the exam yet. Lost motivation. Reviewing topics atm. How about you?

discussion.content:
On further thoughts:
D - 100% - the range configured IS nondefault
B - This depends
"When you define a non-default SRGB range, there MIGHT be a label conflict (for example, if labels are already allocated, statically or dynamically, in the new SRGB range)." 

If that is the case you get an error. Cisco say 
"To remove this conflict, you must reload the router to release the currently allocated labels and to allocate the new SRGB"
Right, "To remove this conflict, you must reload the router to release the currently allocated labels and to allocate the new SRGB." so I would have thought B and D also

I think also correct should be B. When you change default SRGB, router reboot is required.

So B and D

New Link
https://www.segment-routing.net/tutorials/2016-09-27-segment-routing-global-block-srgb/
Page 4
Why not A?

comments.content: Because there needs to be a default route to PE1 IP 10.0.0.14 specifically. To achieve this, you make a static route and then advertise it to ospf with the "default-information originate" command. With A, the OSPF network will have a default route towards CE1 but that does not help reach the Internet breakout at PE1.

choices.B: The local preference attribute can be applied on R3 to influence AS 65513 to use AS 65515 as the secondary path.
choices.C: The weight attribute can be applied on R2 to influence AS 65513 to use AS 65515 as the primary path.
choices.D: The IGP metric can be manipulated on R1 to allow traffic to be load balanced between R2 and R3.
choices.A: The MED attribute can be applied on R2 to influence R1 to use it as the primary path.

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. An engineer has successfully fixed BGP peering issue. R1 has an established eBGP peering with R2 and R3. Which mechanism should the engineer apply in order to steer the traffic correctly?

discussion.content:
'A' is wrong because MED won't be compared unless 'always compare med' knob is used.
'B' and 'C' are also wrong.
'D' is correct answer

'A' is the only option that makes sense, guessing that 'always compare med' must be configured on R1. 'B' and 'C' are obviously wrong, while 'D' would have had some logic only if there was another PE in AS 65513 (which is not the case).

Selected Answer: D
D by process of elimination

Selected Answer: D
D is correct one

I would vote for D.
A - could be correct if we configure 'always compare med' on R1 and assume that for all prefixes advertised by AS65514 and 65515 has same AS_PATH length.
B - Local preference on R3 will influance routers in AS6514 not R1 or AS6513.
C - Weight is router lacal feature will not influance Rq
D - Some level of load balncing is achived by dafult as BGP prefers shortest AS_PATH for certain prefix (Cisco BGP path selection alghortm - rule 4) . If 1-7 rules gives no preference for certain prefix then with rule 8. Prefere lowest IGP metric to BGP next hop we can force traffic to R2 or R3 influancing load distribution.
"B" is correct
d correct
maybe A correct??
Absolutely Local Preference

Selected Answer: B
Of course B
The proposed answer "MED" it totally wrong. The correct answer is Local Preference as it get passed around iBGP peers.
Weight is local to the router while LP allows routers in an AS with multiple exit points to choose which exit point is used to reach a particular NLRI. So, only B is correct !!!
I think the correct one is local preference.
(only other iBGP peers) i think should be local pref.

//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. Which attribute can router 1 alter so that only other iBGP peers prefer to use 192.168.4.2 as the next hop for route 192.168.3.0/24?
